title: WCU looks to break long losing streak at Wofford
text:
WCU looks to break long losing streak at Wofford Keith Jarrett , kjarrett@citizen-times.com 3:33 p.m. EDT October 14, 2015 Coach Mark Speir led the Catamounts to a 26-14 win over Wofford last season, snapping a string of eight straight losses to the Terriers. (Photo: Photo by Mark Haskett) 3 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
ASHEVILLE — As part of its revival season last year, the Western Carolina football program snapped an eight-game losing streak against Wofford. 
The Catamounts' 26-14 victory was part of a 5-2 Southern Conference record that allowed for a tie for second place. 
Saturday's 2 p.m. kickoff on ESPN3 between WCU (3-2, 1-1) and Wofford (3-3, 1-1) in Spartanburg gives the Cats a chance to break another eight-game skid. 
That's how many consecutive games WCU has lost at Wofford, a streak that datesto 1981. 
The Cats have not beaten the Terriers at their place since Wofford joined the SoCon in 1997. 
Both teams are part of a four-team logjam tied for third place in the league, between 2-0 leaders Chattanooga and The Citadel and 0-2 last-place Mercer and Virginia Military. 
Assuming Chattanooga wins at VMI on Saturday, the WCU-Wofford loser falls two games behind the two-time defending regular-season champion Mocs. 
The Cats enter the game on a modest two-game winning streak, beating Presbyterian (33-21) and Mercer (24-21) in Cullowhee with fourth-quarter comebacks. 
The rally last week from a 21-3 deficit against Mercer included two fourth-quarter touchdown drives engineered by reserve quarterback Wes Holcombe. 
Senior starting QB Troy Mitchell exited the game in the third quarter with a shoulder stinger in his right (throwing) arm. 
WCU coach Mark Speir said Wednesday Mitchell is practicing and is expected to play against Wofford. 
"We've got a lot to work on," Speir said. 
"Week in and week out in this league, it's such a tough league. (It's) such a balanced league that you can win every week or you can get your butt embarrassed every week." 
Wofford has embarrassed the WCU defense plenty over the years with its funky triple option run offense, averaging 413 yards per game rushing over the past nine meetings to key an 8-1 record versus the Cats. 
Veteran coach Mike Ayers has his ground game in normal attack mode this season, averaging 261 yards per game rushing. 
WCU ranks next to last in the SoCon in rushing defense, allowing 203 ypg. 
Nevertheless, Ayers said he is impressed with the Cats' defensive play. 
"They've got as physical a defense as there is in the league," said Ayers, whose team winning percentage (85-55, .609) is the best in the SoCon. 
"Our matchups are going to be tough, but at the same time, you like the challenge. Thanks goodness we're playing here at home." 
Playing at home has been very good to the Terriers, who are 77-28 (.728) over the past 18 seasons at Gibbs Stadium. 
"Wofford always plays exceptionally well at home — it's a tough place to play," Speir said. 
"Wofford does what they do. They've done it for years and have been successful at it for years." 
WCU quarterback Troy Mitchell (10) is expected to start Saturday vs. Wofford after suffering a shoulder injury last week. (Photo: Photo by Mark Haskett) 3 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://avlne.ws/1RHMmLq TOP VIDEOS
